body:
Cool, much cleaner implementation =)

I tried out this version on Kubuntu 10.04 and confirmed:
- No _files dir created for sessions without images
- Exception raised if _files exists and is not a directory
- Extension not strictly enforced (this was also true on KDE
  for the previous version; so, good to know that some platforms
  _do_ enforce file extension)

The default extension is still ".htm" rather than ".html" -- is this because
".htm" is listed first, or is it a platform difference?

At some point, it might be nice to have rich_ipython_widget catch OSError
and pop up a warning dialog for the case where non-dir file already exists
(e.g., by having its own export functions that just wrap calls to super.export
in try..except blocks)

Thanks for the fixes,

--Mark

That's interesting that your machine still does .htm by default.  
The default should be set by the dialog.setDefaultSuffix('html') line.  It's peculiar that your Qt apparently doesn't respect that.  I'll check on a few machines today, but I currently only have my OSX laptop available, which does use html.

I'm not especially concerned about the default so much as I am that standard (or any) extensions were prohibited.

Yes, the widget should show a dialog on error.

I tested on my Ubuntu machine (apt installed Qt/PyQt), and it does html by default, not htm I don't know why yours would be different.

I just changed how it works a little bit.  All options are in one dialog, like a normal 'Save As...'.  After some testing, now it accepts standard html/htm and xhtml/xml extensions, and appends the default suffix (html or xhtml) if no suffix or a different suffix is given.  This doesn't allow _any_ extensions, but it behaves better than I had it at first.

Making it a single dialog means you can have a meaningful keyboard shortcut (Save default), which I also added.

Adding '_' back to the filters will allow using any extension, but turns off Qt's addition of the default suffix when there's no extension specified.  I explored it, and didn't see an easy way to nicely handle collision detection and only add the suffix when *no_ extension is given while accepting any other extensions.

For instance, if you had:
save as 'f2' really meaning 'f2.html', and both 'f2' and 'f2.html' existed, you would get notified of both collisions.  I can turn off Qt's collision detection and only use my own, but the native dialog is cleaner and preferable.

I also added the warning dialog when an export subroutine raises an error, for instance if fname_files is a file and not a dir.

This is totally sweet -- really useful to have a keyboard-only save!

I think that the weird issues on my laptop are due to KDE's native
file dialog.  For the current commit, I can save as XHTML or HTML
with inline PNGs, but choosing the "HTML with external PNGs" filter
results in saving with inline PNGs (due to dialog.selectedNameFilter()
returning the wrong filter).

If I set dialog.setOption(QtGui.QFileDialog.DontUseNativeDialog):
- Choosing one of the three filters in the dialog results in
  saving the appropriate file type with the appropriate default
  extension.
- Trying to save "test.html" as HTML with external PNGs generates
  an error dialog when non-dir "test_files" exists.

Likewise, adding With dialog.setOption(QtGui.QFileDialog.DontUseNativeDialog)
to commit 0c115e4 gives ".html" rather than ".htm" as the default extension.

So, this feels more like a bug in Qt's use of the KDE file dialog (or just an oddity of my
laptop -- was your Ubuntu test on a Gnome or KDE desktop?) than something to try to work around on the iPython side.

Ah, very interesting.  I guess this is a problem with having two export modes for html.

What about having the inline/external question be a secondary pop-up, like you see when you save a PNG/JPEG from something like Photoshop?  The normal model for that is: file dialog asks what file you want. After selecting the file, if the filetype has extra options, launch new dialog for those settings.
That should resolve the more important issue. 

It's disappointing that Qt doesn't work well with the native KDE dialog.  It's always better to use native when possible.

Cool, works great for me.  I was worried that the extra dialog would be
distracting, but it actually drives very nicely from the keyboard.

Merge remote branch 'minrk/htmlfix' into trunk.

This branch implements a number of improvements to the HTML save
capabilities of the Qt console, and received extensive reviews.  A
short summary follows, see the pull request page for full details, at
http://github.com/ipython/ipython/pull/170.

Some small issues in the HTML code I noticed when I started playing
with it.

```
* only rich backends support toHtml, so the html/xhtml exports
```

failed
    \* modules were imported inside functions
    \* relpath in image_tag was determined in platform-dependent way
    \* save dialog strictly enforced non-standard '.htm' file extension
    \* when selecting external PNG, the _files dir was always created,
regardless of whether there were any images

Fixes in this commit:

```
* export options do not appear in non-rich widgets
* module imports all at the top
* relpath uses platform independent os.path
* dialog uses standard '.html' by default, but allows any extension
* no _files dir is created if no images are to be exported
```

Closed by 35e407aa6016dae939f475dcc8fe154652bc9b42 (pull request).
Great job, Min, and thanks to Mark for participating in the review!
